**Biography of the Author**

Al-Suyuti wrote his own biography in his book "Husn al-Muhadarah," saying: I only mentioned my biography in this book following the example of the hadith scholars before me, for rarely did any of them write a history without mentioning his own biography in it. Among those who did this: Imam Abd al-Ghaffar al-Farisi in "Tarikh Naysabur," Yaqut al-Hamawi in "Mu'jam al-Udaba'," Lisan al-Din Ibn al-Khatib in "Tarikh Gharnata," Hafiz Taqi al-Din al-Fasi in "Tarikh Makkah," Hafiz Abu al-Fadl Ibn Hajar in "Qudat Misr," and Abu Shama in "Al-Rawdatayn," and he is the most pious and ascetic of them.

**His Name and Lineage:**
Al-Suyuti said: Biography of the author of this book - Husn al-Muhadarah - Abd al-Rahman bin al-Kamal Abi Bakr bin Muhammad bin Sabiq al-Din bin al-Fakhr Uthman bin Nazir al-Din Muhammad bin Sayf al-Din Khidr bin Najm al-Din Abi al-Salah Ayyub bin Nasir al-Din Muhammad bin Sheikh Humam al-Din al-Humam al-Khudayri al-Asyuti. As for our attribution 'Al-Khudayri,' I do not know what this attribution refers to except "Al-Khudayriyyah," a locality in Baghdad. Someone I trust told me that he heard my father, may Allah have mercy on him, say that his great-grandfather was a non-Arab or from the East, so it appears the attribution is to the mentioned locality.

**His Birth and Upbringing:**
Al-Suyuti said: My birth was after sunset on the night of Sunday, the beginning of Rajab, year 849. I was carried during my father's life to Sheikh Muhammad al-Majdhub, a man who was one of the great saints near the Shrine of Nafisa, and he blessed me.
foot_note: None

Al-Aydarus (1) says: His father brought him, when he was three years old, to the assembly of Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Hajar once. While young, he attended the assembly of the hadith scholar Sheikh Zayn al-Din Ridwan al-Utbi, and studied under Sheikh Siraj al-Din Umar al-Wardi. Then he engaged in knowledge with several sheikhs.
Al-Suyuti said: I grew up an orphan. I memorized the Quran before I was eight years old. Then I memorized "Al-Umdah" (2), "Minhaj al-Fiqh" (3), "Al-Usul" (4), and "Alfiyyat Ibn Malik."
Al-Aydarus (5) said: His father died on the night of Monday, the fifth of Safar, year 855. He appointed Sheikh Kamal al-Din Ibn al-Humam as his guardian, so he looked after him with care and attention.

**His Family:**
As for my great-grandfather Humam al-Din, he was among the people of spiritual reality (Haqiqah) and sheikhs of the paths... Those below him were people of status and leadership; some held the judiciary in their town, some held the Hisba (market inspection), some were merchants in the company of Emir Shaykhun and built a school in Asyut and endowed it. Some were travelers. I do not know of any of them who served knowledge properly except my father.

As for his mother, Al-Sakhawi (1) informs us in Al-Daw' al-Lami' that his mother was Turkish. Al-Aydarus (2) says about her: A Turkish Umm Walad (slave mother).

**His Travels:**
Al-Suyuti said: I traveled, praise be to Allah, to the lands of Sham, Hijaz, Yemen, India, Maghreb, and Takrur. He also has a journey within Egypt, mentioned by Al-Sakhawi in Al-Daw' al-Lami' (3), who said: Then he traveled to Fayyum, Damietta, and Mahalla, and wrote from a group.
Then Al-Suyuti said: When I performed Hajj, I drank Zamzam water for several matters: among them to reach in Fiqh the rank of Sheikh Siraj al-Din al-Bulqini, and in Hadith the rank of Hafiz Ibn Hajar.

**His Sheikhs:**
Al-Suyuti took extensively from sheikhs. He gathered their names in a dictionary (Mu'jam) saying: As for my sheikhs in narration via hearing and license (Ijazah), they are many. I listed them in the Mu'jam I collected them in, and they number about one hundred and fifty. I did not increase in hearing narration because I was busy with what is more important, which is reading Dirayah (comprehension/knowledge).
Al-Suyuti said: I started engaging in knowledge at the beginning of the year 864. I took Fiqh and Grammar from a group of sheikhs. I took Inheritance Law (Fara'id) from the Allamah, the Fara'idi of his time, Sheikh Shihab al-Din al-Sharmasahi, who was...
foot_note:
1. (1) Al-Daw' al-Lami' 4 / 65. 
2. Al-Nur al-Safir p. 51. 
3. Al-Daw' al-Lami' 4 / 65. (*)

...said to have reached a very old age, exceeding one hundred by much, Allah knows best. I read with him his commentary on "Al-Majmu'." I was licensed to teach Arabic at the beginning of the year 866. I authored in this year; the first thing I authored was "Sharh al-Isti'adha wa al-Basmala." I showed it to our Sheikh, Sheikh al-Islam Alam al-Din al-Bulqini, and he wrote a eulogy on it. I stuck with him in Fiqh until he died. Then I stuck with his son, reading with him from the beginning of "Al-Tadrib" by his father to "Al-Wakala," and heard from him from the beginning of "Al-Hawi al-Saghir" to (Al-Adad), and from the beginning of "Al-Minhaj" to (Zakat), and from the beginning of "Al-Tanbih" to near (Bab al-Zakat), and a portion of "Al-Rawda" from (Bab al-Qada'), and a portion of "Takmilat Sharh al-Minhaj" by Al-Zarkashi, and from (Ihya' al-Mawat) to (Al-Wasaya) or thereabouts. He licensed me to teach and issue fatwas from the year 876 and attended my first lecture. When he died in the year 878, I stuck with Sheikh al-Islam Sharaf al-Din al-Munawi. I read with him a portion of "Al-Minhaj" and heard him on it in divisions, except sessions I missed. I heard lessons from the commentary on "Al-Bahja" and a gloss on it, and from "Tafsir al-Baydawi."
In Hadith and Arabic, I stuck with our Sheikh Imam Allamah Taqi al-Din al-Shibli al-Hanafi. I attended him regularly for four years. He wrote a eulogy for me on "Sharh Alfiyyat Ibn Malik" and on "Jam' al-Jawami' fi al-Arabiyya" authored by me. He testified for me more than once regarding my advancement in sciences with his tongue and pen. He retracted his own view simply based on my word regarding a hadith; for he cited in his "Hashiya 'ala al-Shifa" the hadith of Abu al-Hamra' regarding Isra', attributing it to Ibn Majah. I needed to cite it with its chain, so I searched Ibn Majah in its expected place but did not find it. I went through the entire book but did not find it. I doubted my sight...

...so I went through it a second time and did not find it, then returned a third time and did not find it. I saw it in "Mu'jam al-Sahaba" by Ibn Qani'. So I came to the Sheikh and informed him. As soon as he heard that from me, he took his copy, took the pen, crossed out the word: Ibn Majah, and appended Ibn Qani' in the margin. I considered that great and was awed by it due to the great status of the Sheikh in my heart and my contempt for myself. I said: Won't you wait, perhaps you might review? He said: No, I only imitated Al-Burhan al-Halabi in saying: Ibn Majah. I did not separate from the Sheikh until he died.
I stuck with our Sheikh, the Allamah, the Master of Existence, Muhyi al-Din al-Kafiji for fourteen years. I took from him the arts of Tafsir, Usul, Arabic, Ma'ani, and others. He wrote me a great license. I attended numerous lessons with Sheikh Sayf al-Din al-Hanafi in "Al-Kashshaf," "Al-Tawdih" and his gloss on it, "Talkhis al-Miftah," and "Al-Adud."
I began authoring in the year 866. My works reached up to now - meaning about twelve years before his death - three hundred books, other than what I washed off and retracted. Al-Aydarus (1) says: His works reached about six hundred, other than what he retracted and washed off.
Al-Suyuti said: I was granted depth in seven sciences: Tafsir, Hadith, Fiqh, Syntax, Ma'ani, and Bayan, according to the way of the Arabs and eloquent ones, not the way of the non-Arabs and philosophers. Below these seven in knowledge: Usul al-Fiqh, Dialectic (Jadal), and Morphology (Tasrif),

and below them Composition (Insha'), Correspondence (Tarassul), and Inheritance (Fara'id). Below them Readings (Qira'at), which I did not take from a sheikh. Below them Medicine. As for Arithmetic (Hisab), it is the hardest thing for me and furthest from my mind; if I look at a problem related to it, it is as if I am trying to carry a mountain. In the beginning of seeking knowledge, I read in Logic (Mantiq), then Allah cast aversion to it in my heart. I heard that Ibn al-Salah issued a fatwa prohibiting it, so I left it for that reason. Allah compensated me for it with the science of Hadith, which is the noblest of sciences.
What I believe is that what I have reached in these seven sciences, other than Fiqh and the transmitted texts I have viewed in them, none of my sheikhs reached, let alone those below them. As for Fiqh, I do not say that about it; rather, my sheikh in it has a broader view and longer reach.
He says: The tools of Ijtihad have now been completed for me. He mentions the motive for this claim of his, saying: I say that speaking of Allah's blessing, not out of pride. What is there in the world to seek its attainment by boasting? Departure has drawn near, gray hair has appeared, and the best of life has gone. If I wished to write a book on every issue with its sayings, transmitted and analogical evidences, its basis, refutations, answers, and balancing between the different schools of thought in it, I would be able to do that by the grace of Allah, not by my power or strength. There is no power nor strength except by Allah. What Allah wills [happens], there is no power except by Allah.

**His Character and Scholars' Praise of Him:**
Najm al-Din al-Ghazzi (1) says: When he reached forty years of age, he began to devote himself to worship, cut himself off for Allah Almighty, occupy himself purely with Him, and turn away...
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-Nur al-Safir p. 52 (*)

text:
...from the world and its people as if he knew none of them. He began editing his works, left issuing fatwas and teaching, and apologized for that in a work he authored named "Al-Tanfis." He resided in Rawdat al-Miqyas and did not move from it until he died. He did not open the windows of his house overlooking the Nile from his residence. Emirs and the wealthy used to come to visit him and offer him precious wealth, but he would return it. Al-Ghawri gifted him a eunuch and a thousand dinars; he returned the thousand, took the eunuch, freed him, and made him a servant in the Prophetic Chamber. He said to the Sultan's messenger: Do not ever come back to us with a gift, for Allah Almighty has enriched us from such things. He did not frequent the Sultan or anyone else. He was summoned repeatedly but did not attend.
Al-Aydarus (1) says: It is narrated about him that he said: I saw in a dream as if I was before the Prophet, peace be upon him. I mentioned to him a book I started authoring in Hadith, which is "Jam' al-Jawami'." I said to him: Shall I read something from it to you? He said to me: Bring it, O Sheikh of Hadith. He said: This glad tiding is greater to me than the world and all it contains.

**His Works:**
Ibn al-Imad (2) says: Most of his works became famous during his lifetime in the quarters of the earth, east and west. He was a great sign in the speed of authorship, such that his student Al-Dawudi said: I witnessed the Sheikh write three quires (kararis) in one day, authoring and editing. With that, he would dictate Hadith and answer contradictory ones with good answers. He was the most knowledgeable of the people of his time in the science of Hadith and its arts, regarding narrators...

...and strange terms (Gharib), text and chain, and deducing rulings from it. He informed about himself that he memorized two hundred thousand hadiths. He said: If I found more, I would have memorized them. He said: Perhaps there is not more than that on the face of the earth now.
Al-Aydarus says in "Al-Nur al-Safir" (1): He was nicknamed Ibn al-Kutub (Son of Books), because his father was a man of knowledge and needed to consult a book. He ordered his mother to bring the book from among his books. She went to bring it, and labor pains came to her while she was among the books, so she gave birth to him.
Najm al-Din al-Ghazzi (2) says: He authored numerous, complete, comprehensive, beneficial, perfected, edited, relied upon, and considered works. Their number exceeded five hundred works. Al-Dawudi exhausted them in his biography... Most of his works became famous during his lifetime in the Hijaz, Sham, Aleppo, Rum (Turkey), Maghreb, Takrur, India, and Yemen. In the speed of writing and authoring, he was a great sign of Allah's signs.

**In the Name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, and in Him we seek help**

Praise be to Allah, the Causer of causes and the Driver of clouds, and prayers and peace upon our Master Muhammad and the Family and Companions... To proceed:
Among the types of Hadith sciences is knowing its causes, like the causes of revelation of the Quran. Imams have authored books on the causes of revelation of the Quran, and the book of Al-Wahidi is famous among them. I have a comprehensive work on it called "Lubab al-Nuqul fi Asbab al-Nuzul."
As for the causes of Hadith, some of the predecessors wrote on it, but we have not come across it; they only mentioned it in his biography. Hafiz Abu al-Fadl Ibn Hajar mentioned it in "Sharh al-Nukhba." I loved to compile a book on it, so I tracked the collections of Hadith and picked fragments from them, gathering them in this book. And Allah is the Grantor of success and Guide to the right path.

**Section**
Sheikh al-Islam Siraj al-Din al-Bulqini said in his book "Mahasin al-Istilah": The sixty-ninth type: Knowing the causes of Hadith.
Sheikh Abu al-Fath al-Qushayri, known as Ibn Daqiq al-Eid, may Allah have mercy on him, said in "Sharh al-Umdah" discussing the hadith: "Actions are but by intentions" in the ninth research: Some late scholars of Hadith began classifying the causes of Hadith, just as was classified for the causes of revelation of the Noble Book. I came across a little of that.
foot_note: None

text:
The hadith: "Actions are but by intentions" falls into this category, and many analogues join this for whoever intends to track it. This is the Sheikh's speech.
Al-Bulqini said: Know that the cause may be transmitted within the hadith, as in the hadith: Gabriel asking about Islam and Ihsan and others. And the hadith: The two Qullahs (large jars), he was asked about water in the desert and what befalls it from carnivores and animals. And the hadith: Intercession, its cause is his saying, peace be upon him: "I am the master of the children of Adam, and no pride." And the hadith: The question of the Najdi. And the hadith: "Pray, for you have not prayed." And the hadith: "Take a piece of musk." And the hadith: Asking about menstrual blood affecting the garment. And the hadith: The questioner: Which deeds are best? And the hadith: Asking which sin is greatest? And that is frequent.
The cause may not be transmitted in the hadith, or transmitted in some of its routes, so that is what should be cared for. Among that is the hadith: "The best prayer of a person is in his house except the obligatory." Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and others from the hadith of Zayd bin Thabit. It was reported in some hadiths in response to a questioner's question, which is what Ibn Majah narrated in his Sunan and Al-Tirmidhi in Al-Shama'il from the hadith of Abdullah bin Sa'd who said: I asked the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him: Which is better, prayer in my house or prayer in the mosque? He said: "Do you not see my house? How close it is to the mosque! Yet to pray in my house is more beloved to me than to pray in the mosque, unless it be an obligatory prayer."
Then Al-Bulqini mentioned several examples and said: What is mentioned in this type of causes, it may be that what is mentioned after that cause from the words of the Prophet, peace be upon him, was the first thing spoken by...
foot_note: None

text:
...the Prophet, peace be upon him, at that time. And he might have spoken it before that, for a similar cause or for no cause. Sometimes it is determined to be the first time he spoke it at that time due to indications. This becomes apparent to one knowledgeable in this field. In the chapters of Sharia and stories and others, there are hadiths that have causes whose explanation would be lengthy. What we mentioned is a model for whoever wants to know that, and an entrance for whoever wants to add an extensive work on that. The hope from Allah Almighty is for help on an extensive work on it by His grace and generosity.
Ibn al-Mulaqqin said in Sharh al-Umdah: Know that some late scholars of Hadith began classifying the causes of Hadith. Sheikh Izz al-Din attributed this to some late scholars, and Ibn al-Attar in his explanation attributed it to Ibn al-Jawzi. I heard someone mention: that Abd al-Ghani bin Sa'id al-Hafiz classified a work on it the size of Al-Umdah. Whoever tracks the hadiths is capable of extracting a group of them, and I hope to undertake it, God willing. End.

Whoever's migration was for a worldly gain he seeks, or a woman he proposes to, his migration is only to what he migrated to." Then he raised his hands and said: "O Allah, remove the epidemic from us" three times. When morning came, he said: I was brought the fever tonight, and behold, it was a black woman held by the neck in the hand of the one who brought her. He said: This is the fever, what do you see? **Chapter on Prayer**

[9] **Hadith:** Al-Bukhari and Muslim (1) narrated from Anas who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever sleeps through a prayer or forgets it, its expiation is to pray it when he remembers it; there is no expiation for it except that, (and establish prayer for My remembrance)."
**Cause:** Abu Ahmad al-Hakim, whose name is Muhammad bin Ishaq the Hafiz, said in a session of his dictations: Abu Ja'far Muhammad bin al-Husayn al-Hinnawi told us, Muhammad bin al-Ala' told us, Khalaf bin Ayyub al-Amiri told us, Ma'mar told us, from Al-Zuhri, from Sa'id bin al-Musayyib, from Abu Huraira that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, on the night he was taken on the night journey (Isra'), slept until the sun rose, then he prayed and said: "Whoever sleeps through a prayer or forgets it, let him pray it when he remembers it." Then he recited (and establish prayer for My remembrance).
I saw in the handwriting of Sheikh Wali al-Din al-Iraqi in some of his collections, citing this hadith with its text: Abu Ahmad al-Hakim narrated it in a session of his dictations and said: Strange from the hadith of Ma'mar, from Al-Zuhri, from Sa'id, from Abu Huraira raised (musnad). I do not know anyone who narrated it other than Khalaf bin Ayyub al-Amiri from this narration, and Aban bin Yazid al-Attar from him, meaning from Ma'mar.
Sheikh Wali al-Din said: It is good to be about the famous answer, which is: Gabriel's explanation did not occur except at Zuhr, and prayer had been obligated at night? It is said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, was sleeping at the time of Fajr, and the sleeper is not accountable. He said: This is a great benefit. And the hadith has an authentic chain. End.
I say: It is not as he said. For the intended meaning in...
foot_note: 1. (1) Narrated by Al-Bukhari in Book of Prayer Times 1 / 154. Narrated by Muslim in Book of Mosques 2 / 334. (*)

text:
...this hadith is the night he traveled (Isra' here meaning night travel) in a journey and slept through the Fajr prayer, not the night he was taken on the night journey to heaven. So the word 'Isra' confused him.
**Second Cause:** Al-Tirmidhi (who authenticated it) and Al-Nasa'i narrated from Abu Qatada who said: They mentioned to the Prophet, peace be upon him, their sleeping through prayer. He said: "There is no negligence in sleep; negligence is only in wakefulness. So if one of you forgets a prayer or sleeps through it, let him pray it when he remembers it."
Ahmad narrated from Abu Qatada who said: We were with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. He said: "If you do not reach water tomorrow, you will be thirsty." The people rushed wanting water. I stuck to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. His mount leaned with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, so the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, dozed off. I supported him, so he leaned. Then he leaned until he almost fell off his mount, so I supported him, and he woke up. He said: "Who is the man?" I said: Abu Qatada. He said: "How long have you been traveling?" I said: Since the night. He said: "May Allah preserve you as you preserved His Messenger." Then he said: "If we rest (sleep)." He leaned towards a tree and dismounted. He said: "Look, do you see anyone?" I said: Here is a rider, here are two riders, until it reached seven. He said: "Guard our prayer for us." We slept, and nothing woke us but the heat of the sun. We woke up. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, rode and traveled, and we traveled a little. Then he dismounted and said: "Do you have water?" He said: I said: Yes, I have a vessel with some water. He said: "Bring it." I brought it to him. He said: "Touch from it." The people performed ablution and a sip remained. He said: "Keep it, O Abu Qatada, for it will have a story." Then Bilal called Adhan, and they prayed the two rak'ahs before Fajr, then they prayed Fajr. Then they rode and we rode. Some said to others: We have neglected our prayer. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "What are you saying? If it is a matter of your world, it is your affair; if it is a matter of your religion, it is to me." We said: O Messenger of Allah, we neglected our prayer. He said: "There is no negligence in...
foot_note: None

text:
...sleep; negligence is only in wakefulness. So if that happens, pray it, and its time is the next day."

[10] **Hadith:** Ahmad (1) narrated from Al-Sa'ib bin Abi al-Sa'ib from the Prophet, peace be upon him, who said: "The prayer of the sitting person is half the prayer of the standing person."
And Al-Bukhari narrated from Imran bin Husayn that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever prays sitting has half the reward of the standing person."
**Cause:** Abd al-Razzaq in Al-Musannaf and Ahmad narrated from Anas who said: When the Prophet, peace be upon him, arrived in Medina, it was fever-ridden, so the people got fever. The Prophet, peace be upon him, entered the mosque while people were praying sitting. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "The prayer of the sitting person is half the prayer of the standing person." So the people forced themselves to pray standing.
Abd al-Razzaq narrated from Abdullah bin Amr who said: We arrived in Medina and a severe epidemic of Medina's fever struck us. People frequently prayed their voluntary prayers sitting. The Prophet, peace be upon him, came out at midday while they were praying their voluntary prayers sitting. He said: "The prayer of the sitter is half the prayer of the stander." He said: So the people then began forcing themselves to stand.

[11] **Hadith:** Al-Bukhari and Muslim (2) narrated from Abu Huraira that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Does one of you not fear, or does one of you not fear, that if he raises his head before the Imam, Allah will turn his head into a donkey's head or turn his form into a donkey's form?"
**Cause:** Ahmad narrated from Abu Sa'id al-Khudri who said: A man prayed...

1. (1) Narrated by Ahmad 4 / 435. 
2. Narrated by Al-Bukhari 1 / 177 and Muslim 2 / 73. (*)

text:
...behind the Prophet, peace be upon him, and began bowing before he bowed and raising before he raised. When the Prophet, peace be upon him, finished the prayer, he said: "Who did this?" He said: I, O Messenger of Allah, I loved to know if you know that or not. He said: "Fear invalidating the prayer. If the Imam bows, then bow, and if he raises, then raise."

[12] **Hadith:** Abu Dawood (1) narrated from Abu Sa'id al-Khudri that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, used to say when he said: "Allah hears him who praises Him": "O Allah our Lord, to You is praise, filling the heavens and filling the earth and filling whatever You wish of anything after. O Worthy of Praise and Glory, the most truthful thing a slave said, and we are all Your slaves. None can prevent what You have given, and none can give what You have prevented, and the wealth of the wealthy does not avail him against You."
**Cause:** Ibn Majah and Abu Muti' in his Amali narrated from Umar who said: I heard Abu Juhayfa, may Allah be pleased with him, saying: Fortunes (Judud) were mentioned in the presence of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, while he was in prayer. A man said: So-and-so's fortune is in horses. Another said: So-and-so's fortune is in camels. Another said: So-and-so's fortune is in sheep. Another said: So-and-so's fortune is in slaves. When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, finished his prayer and raised his head from the last rak'ah, he said: "O Allah our Lord, to You is praise filling the heavens and filling the earth and filling whatever You wish of anything after. O Allah, none can prevent what You have given, and none can give what You have prevented, and the wealth (Jadd) of the wealthy does not avail him against You." The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, prolonged his voice with "Al-Jadd" so they would know it is not as they say.

[13] **Hadith:** The six Imams (2) narrated from Abu Huraira who said: The Messenger of...

text:
...Allah, peace be upon him, said: "If the prayer is established, do not come to it running, but come to it walking, and have tranquility. Whatever you catch, pray, and whatever you missed, complete."
**Cause:** Ahmad, Al-Bukhari, and Muslim narrated from Abu Qatada from his father who said: While we were praying with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, he heard the commotion of men. When he prayed, he called them and said: "What is your matter?" They said: O Messenger of Allah! We hurried to the prayer. He said: "Do not do that. If you come to the prayer, have tranquility. Whatever you catch, pray, and whatever preceded you, complete."

[14] **Hadith:** Al-Tirmidhi (1) narrated from Ali and from Amr bin Murrah from his father from Ibn Abi Layla from Mu'adh who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "If one of you comes to the prayer and the Imam is in a state, let him do as the Imam does."
**Cause:** Al-Tabarani narrated from Mu'adh who said: People in the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, if one of them was late for part of the prayer, he would ask them, and they would signal to him what he missed. He would pray what he missed then join them in their prayer. Mu'adh came and the people were sitting in their prayer, so he sat with them. When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said salam, he stood to make up what he missed. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Do what Mu'adh did." In a narration of his: I said: I will not find him in a state except that I will be on it. So I was in their state in which I found them. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Mu'adh has set a sunnah for you, so follow him. If one of you comes and has missed part of the prayer, let him pray with the Imam in his prayer, and when the Imam finishes, let him make up what he missed."

...peace be upon him said: "Whoever eats from this plant should not approach our mosque until its smell goes away." Meaning garlic. Muslim narrated from Abu Huraira who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever eats from this tree should not approach our mosque, for he harms us with the smell of garlic."
**Cause:** Ahmad narrated from Al-Mughira bin Shu'ba who said: I ate garlic then came to the Prophet's place of prayer, peace be upon him. I found he had preceded me by one rak'ah. When he prayed, I stood to make up. He found the smell of garlic and said: "Whoever eats from this plant should not approach our mosque until its smell goes away." He said: When I finished the prayer, I came and said: O Messenger of Allah, I have an excuse, give me your hand. He said: I found him, by Allah, easy. He gave me his hand, and I put it inside my sleeve to my chest; he found it bandaged. He said: "You have an excuse."
**Cause:** Ahmad and Muslim narrated from Jabir that the Prophet, peace be upon him, forbade onions and leeks at the time of Khaybar. Some people ate them and came to the mosque. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Did I not forbid these two foul trees?" They said: Yes, O Messenger of Allah, but hunger exhausted us. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever eats them should not attend our mosque, for the angels are harmed by what the children of Adam are harmed by."
Ahmad narrated from Abu Tha'labah al-Khushani who said: I fought with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and people were hungry. We found domestic donkeys there and slaughtered them. He said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, was informed, so he ordered Abd al-Rahman bin Awf to call out among the people: "The meat of domestic donkeys is not lawful for anyone who testifies that I am the Messenger of Allah." He said: We found in its gardens onions and garlic...

...and the people were hungry, so they strove and ate. Then suddenly the mosque smelled of onions and garlic. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever eats from this foul plant should not approach us." And he said: "Plundering is not lawful, nor is every fanged beast of prey, nor the Mujaththama (animal tied up and shot)."
Ahmad and Muslim narrated from Abu Sa'id who said: We had barely conquered Khaybar when we fell upon that plant and ate from it voraciously, and people were hungry. Then we went to the mosque, and the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, found the smell. He said: "Whoever eats anything from this foul tree should not approach the mosque." The people said: It has been forbidden, it has been forbidden. That reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, so he said: "O people, it is not for me to forbid what Allah has made lawful, but it is a tree whose smell I dislike."

[16] Al-Bukhari and Muslim (1) narrated from Abu Qatada bin Rab'i, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "If one of you enters the mosque, let him not sit until he prays two rak'ahs."
**Cause:** Al-Bukhari, Ahmad, and Muslim narrated from Jabir bin Abdullah that Sulayk came while the Prophet, peace be upon him, was preaching and sat down. The Prophet, peace be upon him, ordered him to pray two rak'ahs, then turned to the people and said: "If one of you comes while the Imam is preaching, let him pray two rak'ahs and be brief in them."
Ahmad, Al-Bukhari, and Muslim narrated from Abu Qatada who said: I entered the mosque while the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was sitting among the people, so I sat. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "What prevented you from praying two rak'ahs before sitting?" I said: I...
foot_note: 1. Narrated by Al-Bukhari in Book of Shortening Prayer 2 / 70. Narrated by Muslim in Book of Mosques 2 / 526. (*)

text:
...saw you sitting and the people sitting. He said: "If one of you enters the mosque, let him not sit until he prays two rak'ahs."

[17] **Hadith:** Al-Bukhari and Muslim (1) narrated from Zayd bin Thabit that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Pray, O people, in your houses, for the best prayer of a person is in his house, except the obligatory prayer."
**Cause:** Ahmad, Al-Bukhari, and Muslim narrated from Zayd bin Thabit that the Prophet, peace be upon him, made a room in the mosque from a mat and prayed in it for nights. People gathered to him, then they missed his voice and thought he had slept. Some of them began clearing their throats so he would come out to them. He said: "What I saw of your action continued until I feared it would be written (made obligatory) upon you as you stood for it. So pray, O people, in your houses, for the best prayer of a person is in his house, except the obligatory prayer."

[18] **Hadith:** Al-Bukhari and Muslim (2) narrated from Ibn Umar who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "If the heat becomes intense, cool it down by (delaying) the prayer, for the intensity of heat is from the breath of Hell."
**Cause:** Ahmad narrated from Al-Mughira bin Shu'ba who said: We were praying the Zuhr prayer with the Prophet, peace be upon him, at midday. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said to us: "Cool down by (delaying) the prayer, for the intensity of heat is from the breath of Hell."

[19] **Hadith:** Abu Dawood, Ibn Majah, and Al-Hakim (1) narrated from Al-Bara' that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Indeed Allah and His angels send blessings upon the first row."
**Cause:** Ibn Abi Shaybah narrated from Mujahid who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, saw thinness (gaps) in the front row, so he said: "Indeed Allah and His angels send blessings upon the first rows." So the people crowded.

[20] **Hadiths of Tashahhud:** ...
**Cause:** ... Al-Tabarani narrated from Abdullah bin Abi Awfa who said: When the polytheists entered Mecca, they said to their idols: 'You have been greeted and made good' (Hayyitum wa Tubtum). So Allah revealed to His Prophet: Say: (Greetings belong to Allah and good things belong to Allah).

**Chapter on Funerals**

[21] **Hadith:** Al-Hakim in Al-Mustadrak, Al-Mahamili in his Isfahani Dictations, and Al-Daylami in his route narrated from Anas who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Indeed Allah Almighty has angels on earth who speak on the tongues of the children of Adam regarding what is in a person of good and evil."
**Cause:** Al-Hakim (who authenticated it) and Al-Bayhaqi in Shu'ab al-Iman narrated from Anas who said: I was sitting with the Prophet, peace be upon him and his family, when a funeral passed by. He said: "What is this funeral?" They said: The funeral of So-and-so son of So-and-so; he used to love Allah and His Messenger and work in obedience to Allah and strive in it. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him...
foot_note: 1. (1) Mentioned by Abu Dawood in Book of Prayer 1 / 154. (*)

text:
...and his family said: "It has become obligatory, it has become obligatory, it has become obligatory." Another funeral passed by. They said: The funeral of So-and-so son of So-and-so; he used to hate Allah and His Messenger and work in disobedience to Allah and strive in it. He said: "It has become obligatory, it has become obligatory, it has become obligatory." They said: O Messenger of Allah, your saying regarding the funeral and praising it! Good was praised for the first and evil for the last, and you said in both: It has become obligatory, it has become obligatory, it has become obligatory? He said: "Yes, O Abu Bakr, indeed Allah has angels who speak on the tongues of the children of Adam regarding what is in a person of good and evil."

[22] **Hadith:** Abu Dawood (1) narrated from Aisha that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Breaking the bone of the deceased is like breaking it while he is alive."
**Cause:** In a part of the hadith of Ibn Mani', Ibn Mani' said: Muhriz bin Awf told us, Al-Qasim bin Muhammad told us from Abdullah bin Aqil, from Jabir who said: We went out with a funeral with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. When we reached the grave, it was not yet finished. The Prophet, peace be upon him, sat on the edge of the grave, and we sat with him. The digger brought out a bone, a shin or an upper arm, and went to break it. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Do not break it, for your breaking it while he is dead is like your breaking it while he is alive, but bury it in the side of the grave."

[23] **Hadith:** Al-Tirmidhi and Ibn Majah (2) narrated from Abu Qatada who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "If one of you takes charge of his brother, let him shroud him well."
**Cause:** Ahmad and Muslim narrated from Jabir, from the Prophet, peace be upon him, that he preached one day and mentioned a man of his companions who died and was shrouded in an insufficient shroud and buried at night. He rebuked...
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Abu Dawood Book of Funerals. 
2. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi in Funerals 2 / 233 and also Ibn Majah in Funerals 1 / 473. (*)

text:
...The Prophet, peace be upon him, rebuked burying a man at night until prayer is offered for him, unless a person is compelled to that. And the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "If one of you shrouds his brother, let him shroud him well."

[24] **Hadith:** Abu Dawood, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Nasa'i, and Ibn Majah (1) narrated from Ibn Abbas who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "The niche (Lahd) is for us and the trench (Shaqq) is for others."
**Cause:** Ahmad narrated from Jarir bin Abdullah who said: We went out with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. When we left Medina, a rider came speeding towards us. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: It seems this rider wants you. He said: The man reached us and greeted, and we returned the greeting. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said to him: "Where did you come from?" He said: From my family, children, and tribe. He said: "And where do you want to go?" He said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. He said: "You have reached him." He said: O Messenger of Allah, teach me what is Faith? He said: "You testify that there is no god but Allah, and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, establish prayer, give Zakat, fast Ramadan, and perform Hajj to the House." He said: I have acknowledged. He said: Then his camel's foot entered a jerboa hole, so it fell with others and the man fell, landing on his head, and he died. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Bring the man to me." He said: Ammar bin Yasir and Hudhayfah jumped to him and sat him up. They said: O Messenger of Allah, the man has died. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, turned away from them. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said to them: "Did you see my turning away from the two men? For I saw two angels feeding him fruits of Paradise into his mouth, so I knew he died hungry." Then the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: This, by Allah, is of those about whom Allah Almighty said: (They who believe and do not mix their belief with injustice - those will have security, and they are [rightly] guided)
foot_note: 1. Narrated by Abu Dawood in Book of Funerals 2 / 190. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi in Book of Funerals 2 / 254. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i in Book of Funerals 4 / 66. (*)

text:
[Al-An'am / 82]. He said: Then he said: "Take your brother." He said: We carried him to the water, washed him, embalmed him, shrouded him, and carried him to the grave. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, came and sat on the edge of the grave. He said: He said: "Make a niche (Lahd) and do not make a trench (Shaqq), for the niche is for us and the trench is for others."

[25] **Hadith:** Ahmad narrated from Umar bin Hazm that he heard the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, say: "Do not sit on graves."
**Cause:** Ahmad narrated from Umar bin Hazm who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, saw me while I was leaning on a grave, so he said: "Do not harm the owner of the grave."

[26] **Hadith:** Ahmad and Muslim narrated from Anas who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Were it not that you would not bury one another, I would have prayed to Allah to make you hear the punishment of the grave."
**Cause:** Ahmad narrated from Anas who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, entered a garden of the gardens of Medina belonging to Banu Najjar. He heard a voice from a grave. He asked about it: When was this one buried? They said: O Messenger of Allah, this one was buried in the Jahiliyyah. That pleased him and he said: "Were it not that you would not bury one another, I would have prayed to Allah to make you hear the punishment of the grave."
Ahmad narrated from Jabir bin Abdullah who said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, entered a palm grove of Banu Najjar one day. He heard the voices of men from Banu Najjar who died in the Jahiliyyah being punished in their graves. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, came out terrified and ordered his companions to seek refuge from the punishment of the grave.

**Hadiths Prohibiting Cursing the Dead**

[27] Ahmad (1) narrated from Al-Mughira bin Shu'ba who said: The Messenger of Allah...
foot_note: 1. (1) Narrated by Ahmad 4 / 252. (*)

text:
...peace be upon him, said: "Do not curse the dead and thereby harm the living."
**Cause:** Ibn Sa'd, Ahmad, and Al-Hakim (who authenticated it) narrated from Ibn Abbas that a man mentioned Abu al-Abbas (Abbas's father) and insulted him. In a wording: He said to him: I saw Abd al-Muttalib bin Hashim and Al-Ghaytalah, the priestess of Banu Sahm, Allah gathered them both in the Fire. So Al-Abbas slapped him. They gathered and said: By Allah, we will slap Al-Abbas as he slapped him. This reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, so he preached and said: "Who are the most noble of people to Allah?" They said: You. He said: "Indeed Al-Abbas is from me and I am from him. Do not curse our dead and thereby harm the living."
Ibn Sa'd and Al-Hakim (who authenticated it) narrated from Umm Salamah who said: Ikrimah bin Abi Jahl complained to the Prophet, peace be upon him, that when he passed by in Medina, it was said to him: This is the son of the enemy of Allah. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, stood preaching and said: "People are minerals (of various qualities); the best of them in Jahiliyyah are the best of them in Islam if they understand. Do not harm a Muslim because of a disbeliever." The wording of Ibn Sa'd said: "What is wrong with people who harm the living by cursing the dead? Lo, do not harm the living by insulting the dead."
Ibn Asakir narrated in his History from Nabat bin Sharit who said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, passed by the grave of Abu Uhayhah. Abu Bakr said: This is the grave of Abu Uhayhah the wicked. Khalid bin Sa'd said: By Allah, it does not please me that he is in the highest Illiyyin and that he is like Abu Quhafah. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Do not curse the dead and anger the living."
Al-Khara'iti narrated in Masawi' al-Akhlaq from Muhammad bin Ali that the Prophet, peace be upon him, forbade that the slain of Badr from the polytheists be cursed. He said: "Indeed what you say does not reach them, but you harm the living thereby. Lo, indeed foul speech is meanness."
foot_note: None

text:
[28] **Hadith:** Al-Bukhari (1) narrated from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, say: "Indeed Allah said: If I test my servant with his two beloveds and he is patient, I compensate him for them with Paradise" meaning his eyes.
**Cause:** Ibn Sa'd and Al-Bayhaqi in Al-Shu'ab narrated via Abu Zilal from Anas that Gabriel came to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, while Ibn Umm Maktum was with him. He said: When did your sight go? He said: When I was a boy. He said: Allah Blessed and Exalted said: If I take the beloved (Karima) of my servant, he has no reward but Paradise.
Al-Bayhaqi narrated via Hilal bin Suwayd that he heard Anas say: Ibn Umm Maktum passed by us and greeted. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Shall I not tell you what Gabriel told me? Indeed Allah says: It is a right upon Me that from whomever I took his two beloveds (Karimatayh), he has no reward but Paradise."
Al-Bayhaqi narrated from Anas who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Gabriel told me from the Lord of the Worlds that He said: The reward of him whose two beloveds—meaning his eyes—I took away is eternity in My Abode and looking at My Face."

**Chapter on Fasting**

[29] **Hadith:** Ahmad and Muslim (2) narrated from Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, came out to us striking one of his hands on the other saying: "The month is like this and like this and like this, then he reduced his finger in the third."
Ahmad, Al-Bukhari, and Muslim narrated from Ibn Umar who said: The Messenger of Allah...
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Al-Bukhari in Book of Medicine 7 / 151. 
2. Narrated by Ahmad 1 / 184 - And narrated by Muslim in Book of Fasting 3 / 141 (*)

text:
...peace be upon him said: "Indeed the month is twenty-nine, so do not fast until you see it, and do not break fast until you see it. If it is obscured from you, then estimate for it."
**Cause:** Ahmad and Muslim narrated from Jabir bin Abdullah who said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, stayed away from his wives for a month. He came out to us on the morning of the twenty-ninth. Some people said: O Messenger of Allah! We have reached the morning of the twenty-ninth. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Indeed the month can be twenty-nine." Then the Prophet, peace be upon him, clapped his hands three times: twice with all fingers of his hands and the third with nine of them.
Al-Bukhari narrated from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, took an oath regarding his wives for a month, and sat in an upper room of his. He came down on the twenty-ninth. It was said: O Messenger of Allah, you took an oath for a month? He said: "Indeed the month is twenty-nine."
Ahmad narrated from Ibn Umar from the Prophet, peace be upon him, who said: "The month is twenty-nine." They mentioned that to Aisha, so she said: May Allah have mercy on Abu Abd al-Rahman. Did the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, abandon his wives for a month then come down on the twenty-ninth, and it was said to him, so he said: "Indeed the month can be twenty-nine"?

[30] **Hadith:** Ahmad and Al-Nasa'i (1) narrated from Usama bin Zayd who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "The cupper and the cupped have broken their fast."
Abu Dawood narrated from Thawban who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "The cupper and the cupped have broken their fast."
**Cause:** Ahmad and Al-Tirmidhi narrated from Shaddad bin Aws that the Messenger of Allah...
foot_note: 1. (1) Narrated by Ahmad 5 / 210. (*)

text:
...peace be upon him, came upon a man in Al-Baqi' who was being cupped, while he was holding my hand, on the eighteenth of Ramadan. He said: "The cupper and the cupped have broken their fast."
Al-Bayhaqi narrated in Shu'ab al-Iman via Ghiyath bin Kilab al-Kufi, from Mutarrif bin Samura bin Jundub from his father who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, passed by a man in front of a cupper, and that was in the month of Ramadan while they were backbiting a man. He said: "The cupper and the cupped have broken their fast." Al-Bayhaqi said: This Ghiyath is unknown.
Ahmad narrated from Ibn Abbas who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was cupped while fasting and in Ihram and fainted. He said: Therefore, cupping was disliked for the fasting person.

[31] **Hadith:** Ahmad and Al-Tabarani (1) narrated from Ka'b bin Asim al-Ash'ari who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Laysa min am-birr siyam fi am-safar" (It is not righteousness to fast in travel - in the Himyari dialect).
**Cause:** Ahmad, Al-Bukhari, and Muslim narrated from Jabir bin Abdullah who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was on a journey. He saw a man around whom people had gathered and he was being shaded. They said: This is a fasting man. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "It is not righteousness to fast in travel."

[32] **Hadith:** Ahmad, Muslim, and the Four (2) narrated from Abu Huraira who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Do not precede Ramadan by fasting a day or two days, except a man who was fasting a fast, then let him fast it."
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ahmad 5 / 434 - and Al-Tabarani in Al-Kabir. 
2. Narrated by Ahmad 2 / 521. Narrated by Al-Bukhari in Book of Fasting 3 / 35 - Narrated by Muslim in Book of Fasting 3 / 139. (*)

text:
Abu Dawood and Al-Bayhaqi narrated from Ibn Abbas who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Do not precede the month by fasting a day or two days."
**Cause:** Ibn al-Najjar narrated in his History from Ibn Abbas who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Fast upon sighting the crescent and break fast upon sighting it. If it is obscured from you, then count thirty." We said: O Messenger of Allah, shall we not proceed before it by a day or two days? He got angry and said: "No."

[33] Ahmad, Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Abu Dawood (1) narrated from Abu Huraira who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "A woman should not fast while her husband is present except with his permission, other than Ramadan."
**Cause:** Ahmad, Abu Dawood, and Al-Hakim narrated from Abu Sa'id who said: A woman came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, while we were with him and said: O Messenger of Allah, my husband Safwan bin al-Mu'attal beats me if I pray, makes me break fast if I fast, and does not pray Fajr prayer until the sun rises. He said: Safwan was with him, so he asked him about what she said. He said: O Messenger of Allah, as for her saying he beats me if I pray, she recites two Surahs, and I have forbidden her. He (the Prophet) said: "If it were one Surah, it would suffice the people." As for her saying: he makes me break fast, she goes and fasts, and I am a young man and I cannot have patience. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said on that day: "A woman should not fast. And Ahmad's wording: Let none of you women fast except with her husband's permission." As for her saying: I do not pray until the sun rises, we are a household known for that, we hardly wake up until the sun rises. He said: "When you wake up, pray."
foot_note: 1. (1) Narrated by Ahmad 2 / 476 - Narrated by Al-Bukhari in Book of Marriage 7 / 39 - Narrated by Muslim in Book of Zakat 3 / 65. (*)

text:
**Chapter on Hajj**

[34] **Hadith:** Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, and Ibn Majah (1) narrated from Abu Huraira who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Leave me as I left you, for those before you were destroyed by their excessive questioning and their disagreement with their prophets. If I command you with something, do of it what you can, and if I forbid you from something, leave it."
**Cause:** Ibn Hibban narrated from Abu Huraira that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, preached and said: "O people, Allah Almighty has obligated Hajj upon you." A man stood up and said: Every year, O Messenger of Allah? He remained silent until he repeated it three times. He said: "If I said yes, it would become obligatory, and you would not be able to do it. Leave me as I left you, for those before you were destroyed by their excessive questioning and their disagreement with their prophets. If I forbid you from something, avoid it, and if I command you with something, do of it what you can."

[35] **Hadith:** Al-Bukhari and Muslim (2) narrated from Abu Huraira who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Prayer in this mosque of mine is better than a thousand prayers in other mosques except the Sacred Mosque."
**Cause:** Abd al-Razzaq said in Al-Musannaf: Ibrahim al-Makki from Ata bin Abi Rabah who said: Al-Sharid came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, on the Day of Conquest and said: I vowed that if Allah granted you victory, I would pray in Bayt al-Maqdis. He said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, said to him: "Here" is better, three times, then said:
foot_note:
1. (1) Mentioned by Muslim in Book of Hajj 3 / 481. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i in Book of Hajj Rituals. 
2. Narrated by Muslim in Book of Hajj 3 / 537. Narrated by Al-Bukhari in Book of Prayer 2 / 76. (*)

text:
"By the One in Whose hand is my soul, if you prayed here, it would suffice you." He said: "Prayer in this mosque is better than a hundred thousand prayers in other mosques." Ahmad narrated from Al-Arqam bin Abi Al-Arqam that he came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and greeted him. He said: "Where do you want to go?" He said: I wanted, O Messenger of Allah, there—pointing his hand towards Bayt al-Maqdis. He said: "Does trade take you out there?" He said: I said: No, but I wanted to pray in it. He said: "Then prayer here—and he pointed his hand to Mecca—is better than a thousand prayers here"—and he pointed his hand to Sham.

[36] **Hadith:** Ibn Abi Shaybah narrated from Jabir who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Medina is like the bellows; it cleanses its good (sic - likely typo for bad) and expels its filth."
**Cause:** Ahmad, Al-Bukhari, and Muslim narrated from Jabir who said: A Bedouin man came to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and embraced Islam and pledged allegiance to him on migration. Before long, he came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and said: Release me (from the pledge). He said: "I will not release you." Then he came to him and said: Release me. He said: "I will not release him." Then he came to him and said Release me. He said: "No." So he fled. He said: "Medina is like the bellows; it expels its filth and cleanses its good."
**Second Cause:** Ahmad, Al-Bukhari, and Muslim narrated from Zayd bin Thabit that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, went out to Uhud. Some people who went out with him returned. The companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, were divided into two parties: a party saying we fight them, and a party saying no. So Allah Almighty revealed: (What is [the matter] with you [that you are] two groups concerning the hypocrites) [Al-Nisa / 88]. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "It is pure (Taybah), and it expels filth just as fire expels the impurities of silver."
foot_note: None

text:
**Chapter on Sales**

[37] **Hadith:** Ahmad (1) narrated from Ubadah bin al-Samit who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, decreed that there should be no harm and no reciprocating harm, and he decreed that the vein of an oppressor has no right. Ahmad narrated from Ibn Abbas who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "No harm and no reciprocating harm."
**Cause:** Abd al-Razzaq in Al-Musannaf: Ibn al-Tamimi told us, from Al-Hajjaj bin Arta'ah, Abu Ja'far informed me that a palm tree was between two men. They disputed about it before the Prophet, peace be upon him. One of them said: Split it in half between me and you. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "No harm in Islam."

[38] **Hadith:** Ibn Majah (2) narrated that Abu al-Hamra' said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever cheats us is not of us."
**Cause:** Ahmad and Muslim narrated from Abu Huraira that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, passed by a man selling food. He asked him: How do you sell? He informed him. Allah revealed to him: Put your hand in it. He put his hand in it, and behold it was wet. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "He who cheats us is not of us."
Abu Nu'aym and Ibn al-Najjar narrated from Ibn Umar that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, passed by the market of Medina by some food that pleased him. He put his hand inside the food and brought out something that was not apparent. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said 'Uff' to the owner of the food, then called out: "O people, no cheating among Muslims. Whoever cheats us is not of us."
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Ahmad 5 / 327. 
2. Narrated by Ibn Majah in Book of Trade 2 / 749. (*)

text:
[39] Al-Bukhari and Muslim (1) narrated from Ibn Umar that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade selling fruit until its suitability appears (it ripens), forbidding the seller and the buyer.
Muslim narrated from Abu Huraira who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Do not buy fruits until their suitability appears."
**Cause:** Ahmad and Al-Bukhari narrated from Zayd bin Thabit who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, arrived in Medina while we used to trade fruits before their suitability appeared. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, heard a dispute. He said: "What is this?" It was said to him: These bought fruits, and they say: The pomegranate was struck by blight (Tisham). The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Do not trade them until their suitability appears."

[40] **Hadith:** Al-Bukhari and Muslim (2) narrated from Zayd bin Thabit that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, permitted Ariya (selling fresh dates on the tree for dried dates).
**Cause:** Al-Shafi'i said in the Book of Sales: Mahmoud bin Labid said to a man from the companions of the Prophet, peace be upon him: What are these Ariyas of yours? He said: So-and-so and So-and-so, and named needy men from the Ansar who complained to the Prophet, peace be upon him, that fresh dates come while they have no cash in hand to buy fresh dates to eat with the people, but they have surplus of their food from dried dates. So he permitted them to buy Ariyas by estimating them in dried dates from what they had in hand, to eat them fresh.
Al-Shafi'i said: Sufyan's hadith indicates the like of this hadith, which is what Al-Shafi'i narrated from Sufyan from Yahya bin Sa'id from Bashir bin Yasar who said:

2. Narrated by Al-Bukhari in Book of Sales 3 / 96. Narrated by Muslim Book of Sales 4 / 22. (*)

text:
I heard Sahl bin Abi Khaythama say: The Prophet, peace be upon him, forbade selling fruit for dates, except that he permitted regarding Ariya that they be sold by their estimation in dates for their owners to eat fresh.

[41] **Hadith:** Al-Bukhari, Muslim (1), and Abu Dawood narrated from Sa'id bin Yazid from the Prophet, peace be upon him, who said: "Whoever revives dead land, it is his, and the vein of an oppressor has no right."
**Cause:** Abu Dawood narrated via Urwa who said: A man from the companions of the Prophet, peace be upon him, told me—and I strongly think it is Abu Sa'id al-Khudri—that two men disputed before the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. One of them planted palm trees in the land of the other. He judged the land for the land owner, and ordered the palm owner to remove his palms from it. He said: I saw it being struck at its roots with axes, and it was indeed tall palms, until it was removed from it.

[42] **Hadith:** Ahmad (2) narrated via Ata from Jabir bin Abdullah that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "The Umra (life-grant) is inheritance for its people."
Ahmad narrated from Zayd bin Thabit that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, made the Umra for the heir.
**Cause:** Ahmad narrated via Muhammad bin Ibrahim from Jabir that a man from the Ansar gave his mother a garden of palms for her life. She died, and her two brothers came and said: We are equal partners in it. They disputed before the Prophet, peace be upon him, and he divided it between them as inheritance.

[43] **Hadith:** Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, the Four, and Ibn Hibban (3) narrated from...
foot_note:
1. (1) Mentioned by Al-Bukhari in Book of Sharecropping 3 / 139. 
2. Narrated by Ahmad 3 / 297. 
3. Narrated by Al-Shafi'i 3 / 60. Narrated by Abu Dawood in Book of Rent. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi in Book of Sales 3 / 376 and narrated by Ahmad 6 / 80. (*)

text:
...Aisha that the Prophet, peace be upon him, decreed that profit follows responsibility (Al-Kharaj bi-al-Daman).
**Cause:** Abu Dawood narrated from Aisha that a man bought a slave who stayed with him as long as Allah willed him to stay. Then he found a defect in him and disputed with him before the Prophet, peace be upon him. He returned him to him. The man said: O Messenger of Allah! He has used my slave. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Profit follows responsibility."

[44] **Hadith:** Ahmad, Al-Bukhari, and Muslim (1) narrated from Nafi' that Ibn Umar used to rent his farms during the time of the Prophet, peace be upon him, Abu Bakr, Umar, Uthman, and the beginning of Muawiyah's emirate. Then he was told on the authority of Rafi' bin Khadij that the Prophet, peace be upon him, forbade renting farms. Ibn Umar went to Rafi' bin Khadij, and I went with him. He asked him, and he said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, forbade renting farms.
Ahmad and Muslim narrated from Ibn Umar who said: We used to engage in Mukhabara (sharecropping) and saw no harm in it until Rafi' claimed that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade it, so we left it.
**Cause:** Ahmad, Al-Bukhari, and Muslim narrated from Rafi' bin Khadij who said: We were the most farming people of Medina. We used to rent land for the side (produce of a specific part), designated for the master of the land. He said: Sometimes that would be hit (by calamity) and the land safe, or the land hit and that safe. So we were forbidden. As for gold and silver, they did not exist then.
Ahmad narrated from Urwa bin al-Zubayr who said: Zayd bin Thabit said: May Allah forgive Rafi' bin Khadij, I am, by Allah, more knowledgeable about the hadith than him. Only two men came who had fought...
foot_note: 1. (1) Mentioned by Al-Bukhari in Book of Cultivation 3 / 141. Narrated by Muslim in Book of Sales 4 / 49. Mentioned by Ahmad 2 / 64. (*)

text:
...so the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "If this is your affair, do not rent farms." So Rafi' heard his saying: "Do not rent farms."
Ahmad, Abu Dawood, and Al-Nasa'i narrated from Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas that farm owners in the time of the Prophet, peace be upon him, used to rent their farms for what is on the irrigation channels of crops and what was watered by water around the plant. They came to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and disputed regarding some of that. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade them to rent for that and said: "Rent for gold and silver."

**Chapter on Marriage**

[45] **Hadith:** Al-Bukhari and Muslim (1) narrated from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet, peace be upon him, who said: "A woman is married for four things: for her wealth, her lineage, her beauty, and her religion. So succeed with the one of religion, may your hands be dusted."
**Cause:** Ahmad and Muslim narrated from Jabir bin Abdullah who said: I married a woman during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. He said: "O Jabir, did you marry?" I said: Yes. He said: "A virgin or a matron (previously married)?" He said: I said: A matron. He said: "Why not a virgin whom you could play with?" He said: I said: O Messenger of Allah! I have sisters, and I feared she might interfere between me and them. He said: "Indeed, a woman is married for her religion and her beauty, so stick to the one of religion, may your hands be dusted."

[46] **Hadith:** Ibn Majah (2) narrated from Ibn Abbas who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Nothing has been seen for those who love each other like marriage."

2. Narrated by Ibn Majah in Book of Marriage 1 / 596. (*)

**Cause:** Abu Ali al-Hasan bin Ahmad bin Shadhan in his Mashyakha and Ibn al-Najjar in Tarikh Baghdad narrated from Jabir bin Abdullah who said: A man came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and said: O Messenger of Allah! We have an orphan girl who has been proposed to by two men, a wealthy one and a poor one. She desires the poor one, and we desire the wealthy one. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Nothing has been seen for those who love each other like marriage."
Al-Khara'iti in I'tidal al-Qulub narrated from Ibn Abbas that a man said: O Messenger of Allah, in my care is an orphan girl. A wealthy man and a destitute man proposed to her. We like the wealthy one and she likes the destitute one. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "There is nothing for those who love each other like marriage."

[47] **Hadith:** Ahmad narrated from Ali who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "The child belongs to the bed (legal husband/master), and for the adulterer is the stone."
Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated from Abu Huraira who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "The child belongs to the bed, and for the adulterer is the stone."
**Cause:** Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas and Abd bin Zam'a disputed over a boy. Sa'd said: O Messenger of Allah, this is the son of my brother Utba bin Abi Waqqas. He covenanted to me that he is his son; look at his resemblance. Abd bin Zam'a said: This is my brother, O Messenger of Allah, born on my father's bed from his slave girl. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, looked at his resemblance and saw a clear resemblance to Utba. He said: "He is yours, O Abd bin Zam'a. The child belongs to the bed, and for the adulterer is the stone. And veil yourself from him, O Sawda bint Zam'a." So she never saw him.
foot_note: None

text:
**Chapter on Crimes (Jinayat)**

[48] **Hadith:** Abd al-Razzaq, Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Abu Dawood (1) narrated from Abu Huraira that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "The beast is exempt (Jubar - injury caused by it is not compensated), the well is exempt, the mine's injury is exempt, and in the buried treasure (Rikaz) is one-fifth."
**Cause:** Abd al-Razzaq said in Al-Musannaf from Ibn Jurayj from Ya'qub bin Utba, Salih, and Ismail bin Muhammad who claimed that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, decreed that the beast is exempt, the well is exempt, the mine is exempt, and in the Rikaz is one-fifth. He said: The people of Jahiliyyah used to make the tribe liable for what their beasts, wells, and mines caused. When that was mentioned to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, he said regarding that what he said of the decree.
Abd al-Razzaq said from Ibn Jurayj who said: Abd al-Aziz bin Umar informed me from a letter of Umar bin Abd al-Aziz in which: It reached us that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said regarding two men, one hired a mine and the other killed a beast. He said: "What the mine killed is exempt, and what the beast killed is exempt." Jubar in the language of Tihama means waste (Hadr - uncompensated).

[49] **Hadith:** Al-Bukhari and Muslim (2) narrated from Abdullah bin Mughaffal that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade stone throwing (Hadhf) and said: "It does not inflict damage on the enemy nor kill game, but it breaks the tooth and gouges the eye."
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Abd al-Razzaq 10 / 65. Narrated by Al-Bukhari in Book of Diya (Blood money) 9 / 15. Narrated by Muslim in Book of Hudud 4 / 298. Narrated by Abu Dawood in Book of Diya 2 / 52. 
2. Narrated by Al-Bukhari in Book of Slaughters 7 / 112. Narrated by Muslim in Book of Hunting 4 / 641. (*)

text:
**Cause:** Abu Dawood and Al-Nasa'i narrated from Burayda that a woman threw a stone at another woman, causing her to miscarry. That was raised to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and he set the blood money for her fetus at five hundred sheep, and forbade stone throwing that day.

[50] **Hadith:** Ahmad, Al-Bukhari, and Muslim (1) narrated from Jabir that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Do not combine fresh dates and unripened dates, nor raisins and dates in Nabidh."
**Cause:** Abd al-Razzaq narrated from Abu Ishaq that a man asked Ibn Umar saying: Shall I combine dates and raisins? He said: No. He said: Why? He said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, forbade it. He said: Why? He said: A man got drunk, so the Prophet, peace be upon him, gave him the hadd punishment, then ordered to look at what his drink was. Behold it was dates and raisins. So the Prophet, peace be upon him, forbade combining dates and raisins and said: "Each one of them alone is sufficient."

[51] **Hadith:** Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Tirmidhi, and Al-Nasa'i narrated from Ibn Mas'ud (2) who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "There is no one more jealous (protective of honor) than Allah Almighty; for that reason He forbade immoralities, what is apparent of them and what is concealed. And there is no one who loves praise more than Allah; for that reason He praised Himself. And there is no one who loves excusing more than Allah Almighty; for that reason He sent prophets as bringers of good tidings and warners."
**Cause:** Ahmad, Al-Bukhari, and Muslim narrated from Al-Mughira bin Shu'ba who said: Sa'd bin Ubada said: If I saw a man with my wife, I would strike him with the sword not with the flat side. This reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, so he said: "Do you wonder at Sa'd's jealousy? By Allah, I am...
foot_note:
1. (1) Narrated by Ahmad 3 / 294. Narrated by Al-Bukhari in Book of Drinks 3 / 140. Narrated by Muslim in Book of Drinks 4 / 688. 
2. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi in Book of Supplications. (*)

text:
...more jealous than him, and Allah is more jealous than me. Because of Allah's jealousy, He forbade immoralities, what is apparent of them and what is concealed. And no person is more jealous than Allah, and no person loves excusing more than Allah; for that reason Allah sent bringers of good tidings and warners. No person loves praise more than Allah; for that reason Allah promised Paradise."

[52] **Hadith:** Al-Bukhari narrated from Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Help your brother, whether he is an oppressor or oppressed." It was said: O Messenger of Allah, we help him if oppressed, but how do we help him if he is an oppressor? He said: "You hold his hands."
**Cause:** Ahmad and Muslim narrated from Jabir bin Abdullah who said: Two boys fought, a boy from the Muhajirin and a boy from the Ansar. The Muhajiri said: O Muhajirin! And the Ansari said: O Ansar! The Messenger of Allah came out and said: "Is it the call of Jahiliyyah?" They said: No, by Allah, except that two boys struck each other. He said: "No harm. Let a man help his brother whether oppressor or oppressed. If he is an oppressor, let him stop him, for that is his help; and if he is oppressed, let him help him."

**Chapter on Sacrifice (Udhiyah)**

[53] **Hadith:** Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated from Jundub al-Bajali who said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, prayed on the Day of Sacrifice, then preached, then slaughtered. He said: "Whoever slaughtered before praying, let him slaughter another in its place. And whoever has not slaughtered, let him slaughter in the name of Allah."
**Cause:** Ahmad narrated from Jundub al-Bajali that he prayed with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, on the Day of Adha. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, turned and saw meat and sacrificial animals, so the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, knew they were slaughtered before he prayed. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever slaughtered before he prayed, let him slaughter another. And whoever has not slaughtered until we prayed...
foot_note: None

text:
...let him slaughter in the name of Allah."
Ahmad narrated from Jundub who said: We went out with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, on the Day of Adha to people who had slaughtered or sacrificed, and people who had not slaughtered or sacrificed. He said: "Whoever slaughtered or sacrificed before our prayer, let him repeat. And whoever did not slaughter or sacrifice, let him slaughter or sacrifice in the name of Allah."

**Chapter on Foods**

[54] **Hadith:** Al-Bukhari (1) and Muslim narrated from Ibn Umar from the Prophet, peace be upon him, that he forbade on the Day of Khaybar the meat of domestic donkeys.
Ahmad, Al-Bukhari, and Muslim narrated from Abu Tha'labah al-Khushani who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade the meat of domestic donkeys and the meat of every fanged beast of prey.
Ahmad narrated from Zayd bin Khalid al-Juhani that he heard the Prophet, peace be upon him, forbid looting and snatching.
**Cause:** Ahmad narrated from Jabir bin Abdullah who said: When it was the Day of Khaybar, famine struck the people, so they took domestic donkeys, slaughtered them, and filled the pots with them. That reached the Prophet, peace be upon him. Jabir said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, ordered us, so we overturned the pots. He said: "Indeed Allah Almighty will bring you provision that is more lawful for you than this and better for you than this." He said: So we overturned the pots that day while they were boiling. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade on that day domestic donkeys, the meat of mules, every fanged beast of prey, every bird with a claw, and forbade Al-Mujaththama, snatching, and looting.
foot_note: 1. (1) Narrated by Al-Bukhari in Book of Slaughters, Chapter: Meat of Domestic Donkeys. Narrated by Muslim in Book of Hunting, Chapter: Prohibition of eating meat of domestic donkeys. (*)

text:
Ahmad narrated from Khalid bin al-Walid who said: We raided with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, the Battle of Khaybar. The people hastened into the enclosures of the Jews. He ordered me to call out: 'Prayer is gathering (As-Salatu Jami'ah), and none enters Paradise except a Muslim.' Then he said: "O people, you have hastened into the enclosures of the Jews. Lo, the property of those under covenant is not lawful except by right. Forbidden to you are the meat of domestic donkeys, their horses and mules, every fanged beast of prey, and every bird with a claw."

[55] **Hadith:** Ahmad and Muslim (1) narrated from Jabir who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade that any animal be killed by being tied up and shot (Sabran).
**Cause:** Al-Tabarani narrated from Ibn Abbas that the Prophet, peace be upon him, came out to people who had set up a live pigeon and were shooting at it. He said: "This is Al-Mujaththama; it is not lawful to eat it."

[56] **Hadith:** Abu Dawood narrated from Abu Waqid al-Laythi who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Whatever is cut from a beast while it is alive is carrion (Maitah)."
**Cause:** The Prophet, peace be upon him, arrived while they loved camel humps and cut off sheep tails. So he said: "Whatever is cut from a beast while it is alive is carrion."

**Chapter on Etiquette**

[57] **Hadith:** "Visit intermittently, you will increase in love." Ibn Adi narrated it in Al-Kamil from the hadith of Abu Huraira, Ibn Umar, Abu Dharr, and Habib bin Maslama who said the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Visit intermittently, you will increase in love."
Ibn Adi narrated from Ibn Umar who said: We used to say in Jahiliyyah: Visit intermittently...
foot_note: 1. (1) Narrated by Muslim in Book of Hunting, Chapter: Prohibition of killing animals by confinement. Narrated by Ahmad 3 / 111. (*)

text:
...you will increase in love. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said to us: 'Visit intermittently, you will increase in love.'"
**Cause:** Ibn Adi narrated via Ata bin Abi Rabah from Abu Huraira that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "O Abu Huraira, where were you yesterday?" He said: I visited some of my family. In a wording: He said: I visited some of my family from the Muslims. He said: "Visit intermittently, you will increase in love."
Ibn Adi narrated via Ismail bin Wardan from Abu Huraira who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, came out of Aisha's house, and I followed him. Then he came out of Umm Salamah's house, and I followed him. He turned to me and said: O Abu Huraira, "Visit intermittently, you will increase in love."

[58] **Hadith:** Ahmad (1) and Abu Dawood narrated from Jabir bin Abdullah who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, disliked that a man should come to his family (wife) at night (Turuqan). Ahmad's wording: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade that a man knocks on his family at night. In a wording: "If one of you is absent for a long time, let him not knock on his family at night."
Ahmad narrated from Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas that he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade that a man knocks on his family after Isha prayer.
**Cause:** Abd al-Razzaq narrated in Al-Musannaf from Ibn Jurayj from a man from Muhammad bin Ibrahim al-Tamimi that Ibn Rawaha was in a detachment. He returned and came to his house girding his sword. Behold, he saw a lamp. He became suspicious, climbed over, and behold, his wife was lying on a bed with what he saw as a man with disheveled hair beside her. He intended to strike, then piety overtook him, so he pinched his wife. She woke up and said: Back off, back off. He said: Woe to you...

...who is this? She said: My sister, she stayed with me and washed her hair. When that reached the Prophet, peace be upon him, he forbade knocking on women (coming unexpectedly at night). Two men disobeyed him and knocked on their families, and each of them found a man with his wife. When that reached the Prophet, peace be upon him, he said: "Did I not forbid you from knocking on women?"
Ahmad narrated via Abu Salamah from Abdullah bin Rawaha, that he arrived from a journey at night and hastened to his wife. Behold, there was a lamp in his house, and something with his wife. He took the sword. His wife said: Away from me! So-and-so is combing my hair. He came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and informed him. So he forbade that a man knocks on his family at night.

[59] **Hadith:** Al-Bukhari and Muslim (1) narrated from Ibn Umar who said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, led us in Isha prayer at the end of his life. When he said salam, he stood and said: "Do you see this night of yours? At the head of one hundred years from it, no one who is on the surface of the earth will remain."
**Cause:** Ahmad and Muslim narrated from Jabir bin Abdullah who said: I heard the Prophet, peace be upon him, saying a month before he died: "You ask me about the Hour, and knowledge of it is only with Allah. I swear by Allah, there is no living soul on earth upon whom one hundred years will pass."

[60] **Hadith:** Ibn Majah (2) narrated from Abu Juhayfa who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever establishes a good sunnah (practice) which is acted upon after him, he will have its reward and the like of their rewards without diminishing anything from their rewards. And whoever establishes a bad sunnah and it is acted upon after him, upon him is its burden and the like of their burdens without diminishing anything from their burdens."
